“They are hiding people who are sick. Even the ones who have tested positive are not disclosing the names of people they came in contact with," the official said. “We are facing problems in winning the trust of the locals here," he added.

Health Secretary Nitin Madan Kulkarni admitted that one of the greatest challenges for the Government during the pandemic was to establish a dialogue with the residents of Hindpiri and convince them to co-operate with the health workers. "We were left with no option other than sealing the locality," he said.

By now, two cases of Coronavirus have been reported in Ranchi – both from Hindpiri. The first case was reported on March 31 when a Malaysian woman who attended the Tablighi Jamaat congregation tested positive. She was apprehended along with 16 more foreign nationals from a mosque in Hindpiri last month.

The second case –a 54-year-old woman of Hindpiri locality– tested positive on Monday. She had no travel history to any foreign country or affected states within India. The woman has two sons and her husband sells vegetables, sources said. Her family and neighbours are under scanner, they added.

"We are trying our level best to control the spread of the disease in Hindpiri. We are also trying to convince the locals that all these tests are for their betterment, “said Kulkarni.

Officials from the district administration on Sunday said that around 6000 families living in the locality were already screened for Coronavirus symptoms. As many as 200 families were tested on Tuesday. "We are in the process of finding out if the second patient got the infection from the first patient, or she contracted the virus from another person," said Ranchi Deputy Commissioner Rai Mahimapat Ray.

Meanwhile, the Indian Medical Association (IMA) said that the Government needs to tackle the matter with an iron fist and test each resident of the locality. "We have to test all of them. If this becomes community spread, then it will spread across Ranchi," said State IMA President Dr. Pradip Kumar.

Title: Sonalika tractor manufacturer crosses 1 lakh annual tractors sales mark in FY20
Article:
Sonalika Tractors which stands strong as No.1 tractor exporter from India, crossed 1 lakh annual tractors sales mark in FY20.

Speaking on the export performance, Dr Deepak Mittal, Managing Director, Sonalika Group, said, Globally our tractors have been well accepted and appreciated by customers for their technology and consistent performance.

With over 10 lakh satisfied customers globally, it makes me proud to note that we are the no.1 exporter from India with 1.25 lakh customers in markets outside India.

Its a true sign of acceptability of an Indian company across 120 countries. Commenting on the performance, Raman Mittal, Executive Director, Sonalika Group, said, We are making it a habit to win hearts across the globe and continue to drive farm prosperity.

Our customer-centric approach, have been instrumental in this consistent performance of positively influencing over 1 lakh families for 3 consecutive years.

In the midst of current global pandemic, we have taken certain measures to counter Covid19 which includes setting up Isolation Center at St.Stephens Hospital, New Delhi, extension of warranty and service renewal date for our existing customers, disinfection sprayers using tractors and sprayers across the country along with state and local administration, for lockdown period ensuring full wages to our contract workmen and ad-hoc staff along with advance salary for employees in March.”

Mittal added, “as we enter the new financial year, we are ready with 4 Next-Gen Series tractors – Tiger , Sikander DLX, Mahabali and Chhatrapati .In continuation of our belief in constant product innovations, these new tractors are 1st of its kind in India which will offer customization addressing the local needs of farmers.

Title: One more youth tests +ve: Total at 11 in Ujjain
Article:
With one more youth tested positive for coronavirus, the number of coronavirus positive patients reached to 11 till Tuesday in the district. The number of coronavirus positive patients have been on rise gradually in the district.

Medical Officer Nadga, Dr Kamal Solanki, said that on Monday two persons were tested positive while youth was tested positive on Tuesday who was admitted on April 4.

Providing details of the positive patient tested Dr. Solanki said that the patient 22-year-old Mohsin lives near Nagda main road and resides in New Delhi. He was rushed to hospital on April by father after complaining problem in breathing on April 4. At the government hospital after diagnosis he was admitted on the same day and test for Coronavirus was conducted. The test report which was provided on April 7 confirmed him positive with Coronavirus infection.

It was found that the youth came around April 1 -2 to Nagda from Chandan Nagar, Indore in a truck. At present, the administration has referred 9 people of the family to Ujjain and isolated them immediately after receiving the report, he added.

The youth works as a driver and as he had tested positive his area where he lives in New Delhi Kiran Talkies would also be checked thoroughly. The people in and around area would be examined and tested. The entire area is sealed after the incident.

Title: State response team toils 24x7 to help migrant workers
Article:
The Jharkhand Government State Corona Response team has come as a helping hand for thousands of people of the State, who are stuck elsewhere during the 21-day national lockdown due to COVID-19 crisis.

The State Government with Non Government Organization (NGO) PACS Network – Phia Foundation, Jharkhand has set up a control room at state secretariat, Nepal House to help the needy persons. The NGO has joined hands with the Department of Labour, Employment & Training, Govt. of Jharkhand to establish and manage the COVID-19 Response Team (Control Room at State Secretariat, Nepal House).

Excise Commissioner Bhor Singh Yadav, who has been entrusted with the task to look the affairs of control room said, “The control room’s main objective is to help people who are struck at different parts of country once they made a call at the control room.”

Yadav said, “If a person struck in Maharashtra makes call at the control room. Our job is to provide all necessary help and assistance such as food, medicines to needy persons.” Sources said that on an average the control room used to get more than 1000 calls. On the last week of March when lockdown was announced the response team used to get around 1500 to 2500 calls per day, however later the number of calls has dropped drastically with call centre getting 500 calls per day.

The call centre which was launched on March 27 has received 20581 calls till April 7. Similarly, around 728,129 people are stranded across the country. On April 07 the call centre has received 493 calls from different parts of country.

State wise the maximum call is received from Maharashtra followed by Tamil Nadu, Karnataka, Delhi and other states.

The COVID 19 response Team has a strong 200 team members working in 3 shifts (24X7 working hours) belonging to various departments of the State government along with the PACS- Phia Foundation team members.

The team members are registering SOS calls, identifying the place of transit points/ stay locations and listing down the issues being faced by people of Jharkhand currently across other states through toll free helpline Numbers. Everyday call details are categorised State and district wise and shared through the State government to the concerned State for immediate actions.

In a bid to provide relief to people of the State the administration is trying to facilitate the people of Jharkhand who are stuck at different places by providing basic services – health care, shelter and food supply through the concerned State at their point of current stay.

The place of transit point/ stay location was identified along with number of people stranded. Also, the issues being faced by people currently across other states, is listed down and shared with the Chief Minister’s Office and Senior Officials of the Government of Jharkhand.

Title: RU conducts classes via radio, social media
Article:
During the ongoing lockdown, Ranchi University (RU) is conducting classes via its community based radio show and through other social media platforms to maximize time utilization.

The varsity has been conducting classes on its recently launched radio project- Radio Khanchi 90.4 FM since March 8. Lectures on YouTube and popular video meeting app Zoom are also been held on a daily basis for both under graduate and post graduate students.

“Every situation is an opportunity and one must make the best use of it. At this point of time students need to revise what has been previously taught and also concentrate and participate on the online interactive classes. I would also like to say that no one needs to fear Coronavirus. Students should assist the government in its fight against the virus and strictly abide by the rules of the lockdown,” said RU Vice Chancellor Ramesh Kumar Pandey.

The university also has a YouTube channel by the name of Radio Khanchi where all its online audio lectures are available. As many as 126 audio lectures on 19 subjects are available on its channel which has over 1,000 subscribers. Besides the online audio classes, pre recorded classes are broadcasted on its radio show every evening from 6 pm to 9 pm.

Lectures on YouTube are being held since March 22 while on Zoom since April 5 with each session being of about 40 minutes.

“Students as well as teachers have given a very positive response to the classes being held via radio and also online. Apart from the on air classes, Radio Khanchi is also giving the students a chance to showcase their talents,” said Director Radio Khanchi Anand Kumar Thakur.

“Students need to utilize this time constructively. Apart from the lectures being shared on air and online, they can also watch lectures of great professors from RU and other top universities from across the world online on their subjects. Using the latest in technology they can connect with their faculty members on Zoom as well. There is no substitute for a blackboard but present day technology can be beneficial for all,” added Thakur.

Title: Patients to be treated only in COVID Hosps
Article:
All the persons detected COVID-19 positive or having symptoms would be treated only in the seven COVID Hospitals that have come up in the State.

Health Secretary Nikunja Bihari Dhal said, “As of now, there are no COVID-19 patients or suspected coronavirus cases in SCB Medical College Hospital or City Hospital in Cuttack. People are free to visit these hospitals to get treatment.”

There are no COVID19 positive patients in any Government hospitals in the State, except one in the Capital Hospital in Bhubaneswar. The patient has been kept in strict isolation and his recent samples were tested negative for COVID19, Dhal added.

He also urged the people to refrain from visiting hospitals, in case of flu-like symptoms. He rather asked people to call the Government’s helpline no 104 for doctor’s assistance following which all the necessary steps will be taken by the concerned authorities.

Any private hospital which has not been identified as COVID-19 hospital cannot treat coronavirus patients,” said Dhal.

Title: Separate doctors, hospitals for virus patients, suspects
Article:
The State Government on Tuesday said it has separated coronavirus patients from other sick persons in Government hospitals as people fear that they may get corona infection if they visit hospitals.

The Government also said that doctors, nurses and paramedical staffs engaged to treat COVID-19 patients would not handle other patients.

“There is no COVID-19 patient in any of the Government hospitals, including SCB Medical College Hospital and District Headquarters Hospitals. People can freely visit Government and private hospitals without fear,” said Health Secretary Nikunja Dhal.

Though there is one COVID-19 negative person at the Capital Hospital, he would be discharged soon, he said, adding that the private hospitals have been instructed not to admit COVID-19 patients and to refer all cases with flu symptoms to the seven special COVID-19 Hospitals.

Dhal, however, suggested people to use the Telemedicine Helpline and daily 104 control room where doctors are present round the clock to guide.

Director of Medical Education and Training Prof CBK Mohanty said private hospitals have been asked to create separate COVID corners for screening of the patients. If they suspect COVID in any one, they would refer it to a COVID Hospital.

Title: MP Police college provides food for 10,000 people daily
Article:
Police Training College of Madhya Pradesh Police, Indore’s mess is preparing food for 10000 people daily and is provided to needy persons in the time of ongoing Coronavirus pandemic. The kitchen at the training college of MP police at Indore remains busy in the preparation of food for those who are needy daily wage workers and lowly paid workers in the region and are in great need of food.

People are getting to see a new form of police in the hour of crisis due to the global epidemic Corona. People are surprised when police arrive at the hospitals searching for needy for food and corona suspects and provide help to the people affected by the lockdown.

Madhya Pradesh Police have also opened the doors of its training schools to help the people affected by with Corona scare during lockdown. The food is distributed to those who are hand to mouth and have become helpless due to lockdown.

The campus was which witnesses all hard physical training including drills with disciplined steps is now serving people and voices that are heard at the campus are ‘hurry people are hungry and waiting for us’.The district administration is providing subsidized rations and voluntary donors are also helping in the cause.

The employees of Police Training College are working round the clock to prepare food maintaining cleanliness and quality. In Indore city, the district administration had estimated that there are about one lakh people in the city whose living was based on daily income.

Title: 5 miscreants attack two on-duty police personnel with sharp-edged weapons
Article:
Five miscreants who attacked two on-duty police personnel with sharp edged weapons and wooden sticks on Monday night were nabbed by Talaiya police; main accused Shahid Kabutar has been booked under NSA.

At around 11 in the night on Monday two police personnel Satish and Laxman Yadav were attacked at Islampura area by miscreants who were nabbed in the search operation in which teams raided several places during the investigation.

The two police personnel posted with Talaiya police were attacked after they suggested roaming people outside their houses to remain indoors but instead of listening to the victim police personnel a group headed by Shahid alias Kabutar replied in violent manner injuring the two victims.

The victim sustained injuries in hands and shoulders in bid to save and after they managed to reach the police station they alerted and informed senior police officers.

Laxman Yadav sustained injury in his left shoulder while Satish Kumar sustained injury in his left hand. Main accused has been booked under NSA and all accused have been booked under sections 307, 148, 149, 353,341,323,34 and 188 of the IPC.

Apart from the main accused Shahid Qureshi alias Kabutar (31) remaining four accused were identified as Nafees Qureshi (28), Shahrukh Khan (26), Mohammad Javed (40) and Mohsin Khan alias Kachori (27).

The main accused is a habitual offender and has been booked for 13 crimes in the past.

Mohsin has booked twice while Javed has been thrice. The accused have been booked serious offences, said police.

Title: Various organisations join hands to help poor and needy
Article:
In the lockdown situation, due to outbreak of Coronavirus, various organisations have joined hands to help the needy.

This initiative has been started through various organizations and social activists under the aegis of Pujya Bhante Shakyapunna Sagar Thero from Bhopal.

One of the group members Swati said that through this group, it is being urged from every section of the society that they should extend their hand to establish compassion, brotherhood in the society, and help the homeless and other needy people.

The specialty of this cooperation group is that this group is making a list in society based on this standard as well as other standards in order to reach the needy as much as possible. The list includes students who live in hostels, office employees, people associated with art, dance and other arts, who are suffering due to lockdown, housekeepers living in colonies.

Till now many organisations and individuals have joined, including youngsters. Organisations including Budhbhoomi Mahavihara Dhamdut Sangh, MAC Dance Cultural Institute, Pujya Bhante Shakyapunna Sagar, MSK Batham, IAS, Sahebrao Sadavarte, Chandramprakash Golit, Ramprasad Siloriya, Chandrabhan Wasnik, Age. Sanjay Gajbhiya, Ayushmati Shobha Chahande, Swati Asha, Age.

Rameshwar Gajbhiye,Charadas Bodhante, Santosh Shirsat, Harimani Chaudhary, Panchsheela Ganveer, Kumar Dinesh Jindolia and other partner institutions are helping needy people of their respective colonies.

Title: Online competition ‘Corona Par Shabdbaan' held
Article:
The artists of the city can present their creativity through an online competition 'Corona Par Shabdban'. An online competition 'Corona Par Shabdbaan' is being organised for city artists and poets. Sewarth Samuh organisation of Ratlam has called for enetries based on different genres of arts. The last date of submission is April 8 i.e. Wednesday.

The event is being organised with an aim to spread awareness about Corona Virus. The serious outbreak of the Novel Corona Virus have called for a lockdown situation in the entire country. So, to spread awareness about it and to bring out the artists in people and work constructively and artisticly, the competition is being organised.

All successful participants will be rewarded by organizing a special award ceremony by the group.

The first three winners will be awarded. The competition is all about singing, rap, speech, poem or a video. The participants need to shoot a video of theirs reciting a poem, giving a speech or rapping or singing a song on Corona.

The video should stretch at 60 to 80 seconds maximum. Besides, the participants have to submit their art work which talks about Corona Virus and dangers caused by it.

The participant first has to write the mobile number and the name. Then, send it to the organisation on its website or whatsapp mobile number.

Title: Police book over half dozen people for attacking JCB operator
Article:
Khajuri police have booked over half a dozen people for attacking a 30-year-old JCB operator with iron roads and wooden stick near a temple in the evening on Sunday; accused attacked after victim asked for money of work which he did few days ago for the accused.

According to police the victim Deepak Patidar of Tumda village was attacked by Awdesh, Prashant and Ramlal after a heated argument.

The victim Deepak was rushed to a nearby hospital where he was provided with treatment and is reportedly stable.

In his complaint victim stated that he had gone to temple in the evening at around 6 where Awdesh for whom he had completed work using JCB few days ago came along with Prashant and Ramlal. The victim asked for money for the work of filling at under construction house of Awdesh at Patania village but at the spot they started to abuse Deepak and later attacked him.

Soon Bhagwan Prajapati, Rajendra Thakur and other villagers also joined the three and they thrashed him brutally and threatened him of life if he would again demand money.

After the attack victim managed lodged complaint against the three accused. The victim went to the spot only after Awdesh confirmed that they could talk near a temple in the area but was abused and attacked.

The police have registered a case of assault and threatening of life against accused involved in the crime and started to search for accused who are absconding.

Title: Admin ensures help to needy, poor during lockdown period
Article:
Since the announcement of lockdown in country by Prime Minister Narendra Modi with an aim to break the chain of novel coronavirus, the Ranchi district administration has taken several initiatives to ensure that no one is required to move out of their homes.

Home delivery of essential goods was started in collaboration with various service providers for door to door supply of grocery items for which many helpline numbers were also issued. Apart from this, a mobile number was also released along with a list of volunteers to carry essential goods to every area of Ranchi.

In addition, the district administration has also issued the mental health helpline has been issued to help in mental health, including supply of medicines, medical consultation. An additional helpline service has been started in the entire Ranchi to ensure that no person falls asleep. On which any person can give information about any person / family by calling, due to which the means of earning is not able to provide food.

Apart from this, after sealing Hindpiri area as two positive cases of novel coronavirus was detected in the area, a special helpline service has been started for it. At the same time special helpline service was started to ensure door-to-door doorstep delivery of gas cylinders.

After the announcement of the lockdown, the Ranchi district administration is doing everything possible to help its people. Apart from the distribution of grocery, food items, milk, medicines, bread, gas cylinders etc., a dedicated helpline for mental health, medical counseling for senior citizens and the helpline is currently operational.

In one of the many complaints received through the helpline, an elderly couple reported the urgent need for a cell phone. Cell phone delivery was done to the complainant with the help of response team. In another complaint, a senior citizen asked for help regarding gas cylinder booking assistance, another told about the shortage of gas cylinders, the complaint was sent to the gas cylinder distribution team. In both cases the problem was resolved by taking quick action. In another complaint, a senior citizen informed the helpline about his broken leg. Also, he did not have money for his treatment. Taking quick action, the response team reached the spot and was admitted at Sadar Hospital Ranchi.

Talking about this initiative, DC Ranchi, Rai Mahimapat Ray said, “We are continuously striving to fight this Covid-19 crisis. We are looking at the proactive approach after the Prime Minister announced the lockdown across the country. The district administration is always ready to help the needy persons.”

Apart from these the Chief Minister Kitchen is providing great relief to the poor, helpless and needy during the ongoing lockdown period. The Chief Minister Kitchen is running in various Panchayats in 18 blocks of Ranchi district. The Chief Minister's Kitchen is being operated in all 305 panchayats of the district. This initiative has been taken by the Ranchi District Administration with a view to avoid food problems in front of helpless, poor, laborers and the needy during lock down.

With the 299 Chief Ministers Kitchen operating in various panchayats, the poor are being fed. On 06 April 2020, food was provided to 20394 people through all these Chief Ministers Kitchen. Also the district administration is running Daal Bhaat centers at different parts of district. 71 Dal Bhaat centers are being operated in various panchayats of Ranchi district. 19685 people benefited from these Dalbhat centers on 06 April 2020. There are 31 Dal Bhaat centers, 22 special Dalbhat centers and 18 additional Dalbhat centers in the district.

Title: Hot and humid weather conditions prevail in State
Article:
Hot and humid weather conditions prevailed in the State on Tuesday while Jabalpur and Hoshangabad divisions witnessing rainfall in the past 24 hours. The pattern of soaring temperatures continued on Tuesday and in the next 24 hours Shahdol division and around ten districts are likely to witness rainfall and thundery activities.

Very few places recorded rainfall in the state. Nainpur recorded 3 cm of rainfall while Bichhiya recorded 1 cm of rainfall in the past 24 hours in the state.State capital recorded day temperature at 38.3 degree Celsius while night temperature was recorded at 21.2 degree Celsius.

Forecast claims that day temperature is likely to record at 39 degree Celsius while day temperature would be recorded around 21 degree Celsius. The east Madhya Pradesh region remained hot as compared to east Madhya Pradesh region on Tuesday. Shahdol division and Sehore, Hoshangabad, Chattarpur, Damoh, Katni, Datia, Shivpuri,Betul, Chhindwara and Betul districts are likely to receive rainfall and thundery activities.

Met department has issued warning of thndery actities and speedy winds in Shahdol division and Sehore, Hoshangabad, Chattarpur, Damoh, Katni, Datia, Shivpuri,Betul, Chhindwara and Betul districts in next 24 hours. Hoshangbad recorded day temperature at 40.2 degree Celsius. Khandwa recorded day temperature at 40.1 degree Celsius. Several regions recorded day temperature at 39 degree Celsius.

Ratlam, Shajapur, Guna, Raisen recorded day temperature at 39 degree Celsius. Apart from day temperatures night temperatures have soared in past 3- 4 days. Khargone recorded night temperature at 27 degree Celsius.

Title: ‘Waive 3 months’ bank interest for MSMEs'
Article:
The EFCAI has urged the Union Finance Minister for waiver of three months' bank interests on Term Loans and Working Capital or to consider a moratorium of 6 months, after which the accumulated amount calculated at 50% of existing rate of interest can be paid in next 24 months.

The organisation thanked the Government for shifting MSMEs' EMIs and Bank interest by three months.

"Shifting of EMIs by three months could be a good idea but no interest should be charged on this amounts as it will be extremely difficult for MSMEs to service the Term Loan or Working Capital interests. What MSMEs also need is liquidity support," said EFCAI working chairperson Harendra N Mahapatra.

It said 50 per cent of the existing limit to a maximum of Rs 1 crore can be sanctioned as working capital for all MSMEs with GST registration and with a turn over not exceeding Rs 25 crore per annum. This liquidity support must be provided by respective bankers by April 30, 2020 so that businesses could reach normalcy by June.

The EFCAI also forwarded the copy of the memorandum to Union Minister of State for MSME, MSME Minister, Odisha and the Governor of Reserve Bank of India.

Title: Woman, son seek COVID fund
Article:
Distressed Charulata Behera, 58, with her damaged left knee and her 17-year-old handicapped son Umakant are almost bedridden at their house at Andharua on the city outskirts here.

The ongoing coronavirus-related lockdown has added to their woes of penury. They have urged the Chief Minister to provide financial support to them from the COVID-19 fund of the CMRF.

The mother-son duo has brought their plight to the notice of the local BDO, the Khordha district Collector and the CM, informed social activist Kabiraj Sahoo.

Title: Man dies as dumper hits bike at Joda
Article:
Even as the humanity is struggling to fight out the coronavirus, the mining town of Joda in Keonjhar district is witnessing fatal road accidents almost every day.

While locals expected that at least they would get temporary respite from dust, smoke and road accidents during the lockdown period, to their surprise more heavy vehicles are now on the move.

One Ashwini Kumar Rout, who owns a small hotel at Bileipada under Joda block, was returning home by a motorcycle after buying medicine when an iron ore-laden dumper from the DR Patnaik Mines, Murgabeda hit him. He was shifted to a hospital, where he was declared dead.

Locals alleged that reckless driving, bad roads due to plying of heavy vehicles and lack of checking by police during the lockdown period led to the mishap. They demanded adequate compensation for the family of the deceased.

Title: DAV Pokhariput imparts lessons online
Article:
The DAV Public School Pokhariput here commenced online classes for its students from UKG to Class-XII from March 23 to help its students continue their studies in their stay-home environment.

While this initiative keeps the younger ones engaged in various educative activities, it gives the opportunity to the senior students to pursue their studies effectively.

Using various web-platforms available, the teachers of the institutions are reaching out to their students for virtual classrooms.

The students are enthusiastically participating in the programme and are eagerly communicating with their teachers.

"When the world is fighting against COVID-19 valiantly, we are training our students how to grow emotionally and academically in difficult situations," said Principal of the school Dr Sujata, emphasizing on the objectives of web-based classes.

Sameeksha Dash, a student of Class-X, remarked that she is very happy to talk to her teachers and friends online and learn very comfortably at home.

Parents seeing their wards engaged meaningfully in curricular and co-curricular activities are appreciating this initiative. Dr Sujata has appealed to the parents and the students alike to take the best benefit of the online classes and stay safe at home to help the Government keep everyone protected.

Title: ‘Steam, alcohol inhalation may prove better’
Article:
There is no specific treatment for disease caused by novel coronavirus or Covid-19. The virus seems to be very contagious and has quickly spread globally being declared as pandemic by the WHO.

Analysis of physicochemical parameters revealed that the SARS-CoV-2 3CLpro polypeptide is 306 amino acids long with a molecular weight of 33,796.64?Da and a GRAVY score of -0.019, categorising the protein as a stable, hydrophilic molecule capable of establishing hydrogen bonds. These viruses are sensitive to UV rays and heat also can be effectively inactivated by lipid solvents including ether (75 per cent), ethanol, chlorine-containing disinfectant, peroxyacetic acid and chloroform except for chlorhexidine.

Designing safe and effective antiviral drugs is difficult because viruses use the host's cells to replicate. This makes it difficult to find targets for the drug that would interfere with the virus without also harming the host organism's cells.

Moreover, the major difficulty in developing vaccines and anti-viral drugs is due to viral variation.

A new study shows that moderate drinkers on average have lower risk of lung disease than non drinkers. Drinking alcohol moderately, of course not in a regular habit, may help lungs to breathe easy, says Dr Manas Ranjan Senapati, Dean, Science, BPUT, and Professor of Chemistry in Trident Academy of Technology, Bhubaneswar.

Inhalation of steam and alcohol may prove better to perish COVID-19 virus which needs more research, Dr Senapati added.

Title: KV teacher uses app to impart lesson
Article:
Manash Ranjan Sahoo, PGT (Computer Science) of Kendriya Vidyalaya No.4, Neeladrivihar, Bhubaneswar, has an alternative way of imparting education through online mode by the help of software like Zoom and Google classroom. He is teaching Computer Science and Informatics Practices.

In March and April due to sudden lockdown in the State due to Carona, the education system came to a standstill and now the classes are badly hampered. He, however, has taken a step to continue imparting education of his subject to students through the video conferencing app.

Sahoo is not only teaching his subjects to students but also helping other teachers to start online classes among students. Students and parents of KV No. 4, Bhubaneswar are feeling happy to have regular class in the subject at least at the current scenario.

Title: ‘Let parents give time to kids now’
Article:
Prasanta Kumar Mohapatra, a teacher, is giving priority to make his two tiny children learn extracurricular activities during the lockdown period now.

"My heart really aches, seeing my small son and daughter locked inside the four walls for weeks. Though I have gone to local markets to buy groceries, veggies and even medicines many times, the small kids have not requested me for once to take them for an outing to a park, to a food plaza, to the market or at least to the street vendor for Panipuri.

Thanks to the Doordarsan which has brought back the sweet old days of Ramayana and Mahabharata. Children have found some means to remain confined in houses, learning our great cultural heritage," said Mohapatra, TGT Maths, Kendriya Vidyalaya, Kandhamal.

He said he is now making them learn drawing, painting, story and poem writing, book reading and more such creative and imaginative activities along with slow and steady browsing through the next class syllabus.

Mohapatra requested all parents to make their children learn some kind of activities that would develop their personality in future.

"Amongst all, in our struggle for existence in the wake of corona, the children are the most praiseworthy. I salute the whole children community," he said.

Title: Briefs
Article:
Odia woman dies of corona in US

Bhubaneswar: Sunanda Panda, a non-resident Odia woman in New Jersey, US, died reportedly due to COVID-19. She was 50. She was asymptomatic and complained of uneasiness in breathing on Monday and was admitted to a hospital, where she was diagnosed with COVID-19 and put on a ventilator. However, she died within hours. She is survived by her husband and a daughter.

Tigiria lawyer Surya Mohanty passes away

Athagarh: Tigiria’s eminent lawyer Suryanarayan Mohanty (63) passed away on Sunday. He was suffering from pneumonia and cancer. Mohanty was also a good scriptwriter, artist, drama director, short story writer and social worker. He was associated with several socio-cultural-religious organisations of Athagarh and Tigiria. His well-wishers visited his Nizigarh residence to pay him last respects. Principal Mamata Mishra of Athagarh Women's College, Athagarh Bikash Parishad president Ramnarayan Mohanty, ‘Athagarh Prahari’ editor Babita Das and many other prominent persons of the locality condoled Mohanty’s demise.

Bhapur PS staff donate day's salary to CMRF

Bhapur (Nayagarh): The staffs of Bhapur block Panchayat Samiti on Monday donated their one day's salary to Chief Minister's Relief Fond for curbing coronavirus outbreak. They deposited a total of Rs 51,760 in the CMRF account at the SBI, Bhapur Branch here.

Title: Coaching for Class-X students through ‘Diksha’
Article:
In a significant move to ensure that education of matriculation examination aspirants do not suffer due to the corona-related lockdown, the State Government on Tuesday announced that Class-X students would be given coaching online through the mobile app ‘Diksha’,

A complete blueprint for the initiative would be prepared after April 14, said School and Mass Education Minister Samir Ranjan Dash.

He told reporters that teachers have been asked to guide the students, who would be promoted to Class-X, through the Diksha app as they would appear in the annual matriculation examination this academic year.

The Diksha app, launched by the Union Ministry of Human Resource and Development, is a common platform that offers teachers, students and parents engaging learning materials relevant to the prescribed school curriculum.

Title: ‘Giving is in my blood’ accepted abroad
Article:
Blood banks are in dry condition as mass blood donation has been banned by the Government for social distancing required to curb the COVID-19 outbreak.

While thalasemia patients , pregnant, cancer and other critical patients are facing problems in getting blood, blood donation motivator Laxman Swain had started a challenge "Giving is in my blood" with donating blood to a thalassemia patient at the Capital Hospital here 10 days back.

He had also requested others to donate blood at the nearest blood banks to bridge the gap between donors and receivers.

Many donors from different districts of Odisha and other States joined the campaign and donated blood during the last 10days for the great cause of society. Hundreds of blood units have been colleced at different blood banks.

A donor named Kushal Banset from Bijulikot of Ramechhap district of Nepal also accepted the challenge and donated blood at Thapathali Hospital, Kathamandu.

Ramanarayan Dash, Smruti Ranjan Pani, Ramdas Panda, Dipti Ranjan Biswal , Kamal Kumar Dash, Jagneswar Panda, Manoj Panda, Gopal Behera, Jashketan Meher, Sudhansu Meher and others motivated the donors to join the campaign.

Title: DAV staffers give Rs 25L to CMRF
Article:
The DAV Group of Institutions has always come forward to extend their helping hands to the nation at the hour of crisis as a part of social responsibility.

When the entire world is gripped with the (COVID-19) pandemic, DAV College Managing Committee New Delhi, president Dr Punam Suri has donated Rs 5 crore to the Prime Minister Relief Fund. In the recent past, he had also contributed Rs 2 crore to Odisha CM's Relief Fund (CMRF) for Fani victims.

The staffs of around 32 DAV Schools of Odisha Zone have also contributed two days' salary towards PM Fund and CMRF.

A cheque of Rs 25 lakh was given to the CMRF by Dr KC Satapathy, Regional Officer, DAV Institutions (Odisha Zone-I) for utilisation in the fight against the corona pandemic.

Title: Intelligence Bureau office sealed
Article:
In a bid to prevent the spread of COVID-19, the Bhubaneswar Municipal Corporation (BMC) has sealed the office of Intelligence Bureau (IB) here and kept all its employees under home quarantine.

Reportedly, one of the employees of the IB office had come in contact with a COVID-19 positive patient, following which the BMC decided to seal the office.

The IB office located at RN Singh Deo Marg has been sealed for a period of 14 days from April 6 to 19. Sanitisation and other disinfection drives would be undertaken by the BMC during the period, said an official.

“All employees have been kept under home quarantine and their swab samples sent for testing,” informed BMC Commissioner Prem Chandra Chuadhary.

Title: State fails to curb human-elephant conflicts: WSO
Article:
While on Monday, four people were killed in three separate incidents of elephant attack within hours in Padampur of Bargarh, since April 1, four have perished in similar incidents.

Notably, on April 1, three of a family in Jujumora block of Sambalpur district were killed; and on April 4, a 60-year-old woman was killed in Hatadihi block in Keonjhar district.

The eight human deaths in just six days are ominous signs that this year may be worse than previous year which recorded the highest number of 115 human deaths caused by elephants ever in the State.

"Odisha’s Forest department has done precious little to contain the rise in conflict. They are clueless about mitigating the conflict. While previous mitigation plans provided by experts more than two decades ago remain on paper; more and more studies are carried out by external consultants. One private consultant body has been awarded a contract for Rs 3.67 crore to provide a wildlife conflict management plan but it has yet to submit his report though five years have passed.

The alarming casualty figures shows that Odisha’s control over human-elephant conflict is dismal though crores of rupees is being spent on mitigation measures, alleged the Wildlife Society of Orissa (WSO).

The WSO first wrote to the IGF and Director (Project Elephant), Ministry of Environment, Forests and Climate Change on January 21, requesting for intervention to control the spiralling number of human casualties. A month later, on not getting a response and with more reports of human casualties, a reminder was sent to Project Elephant on February 24 reiterating that the situation in Odisha is extremely worrying and the mitigation measures being carried out in Odisha is hopelessly inadequate.

A request was made once again to immediately constitute an Expert Committee consisting of experienced elephant experts and conservationists to assess the situation, identify the reasons behind human kills, and, suggest short term and long term solutions. However, they have failed to take cognizance of the burning problem in Odisha, lamented WSO secretary Biswajit Mohanty.

"The WSO has been specifically pointing out how illegal and rampant quarrying by night blasting, operation of crushers in forest areas and movement of thousands of trucks and tractors in Hindol and Sadar block of Dhenkanal have prevented easy elephant movement.

They are forced to nearby villages where they have killed humans. Similarly, lack of radio collaring of aggressive tuskers in Angul district that has large coal mines has prevented daily monitoring. Our repeated pleas since four years to the Forest Minister to review elephant conflict every month has gone unheeded so far," Mohanty added.

Title: State GST posts highest 24.46% growth
Article:
The State registered 24.46 per cent growth in SGST collection during the Financial Year 2019-20 compared to the ptevious year.

While Rs 7,008.07 crore had been collected in 2018-19, the collection figure rose to Rs 8,722 crore in 2019-20.

Similar trend was observed in CGST collection also. It grew from Rs 5296.07 crore in 2018-19 to Rs 6534.36 crore in 2019-20, registering a growth rate of 23.38 per cent.

Cess has shown a marginal growth of 1.44 per cent with Rs 5722.58 crore collected in 2019-20 against Rs 5641.41 crore in 2018-19.

However, growth in IGST continues to show negative trend with a collection of Rs 8707.38 crore during 2019-20 against Rs 9006.15 crore collected in 2018-19. Thus, a negative growth rate of 3.32 per cent occurred.

The adverse impact of COVID-19 can be seen from the fact that f?in March 2020 the gross GST collection remained almost stagnant as a mere 0.27 per cent was recorded. However, the annual gross GST collection (CGST, IGST, SGST & Cess) during 2019-20 showed a positive growth of 10.11 per cent with total collection coming to Rs 29,677.26 crore against Rs 26,951.7 crore in preceding year.

The SGST annual growth rate of 24.46 per cent achieved by Odisha is the highest growth rate amongst the major States.

During 2019-20, as many as 49,249 new taxpayers were brought to the GST fold in Odisha. Amongst non-GST revenue sources, collection of VAT on petroleum products was Rs 5679.25 crore registering a growth of 0.18 per cent. Similarly, collection of VAT on alcohol for human consumption in 2019-20 was Rs 1,767.44 crore, collected at a growth rate of 8.37 per cent. The professional tax collection also showed a growth rate of 5.54 per cent with collection of Rs 215.10 Crore.

In order to provide relief to taxpayers suffering due to outbreak of Covid-19, Government has recently announced a number of measures.

The last date of filing of GSTR-3B due in March, April and May 2020 has been extended till the last week of June 2020 for taxpayers having aggregate annual turnover less than Rs 5 crore without charging of interest, late fee and penalty.

For others, the same would attract a reduced rate of interest 9% per annum from 15 days after due date (current interest rate is 18% per annum).

Title: SOG Havildar dies in grenade blast
Article:
A Havildar died in a grenade explosion at the Special Operations Group (SOG) training centre at Chandaka on the outskirts of Bhubaneswar on Tuesday.

Two other police personnel were injured in the mishap. The deceased was identified as Prakash Sahu, a resident of Bargarh district.

Reports said the practice of lobbying live grenades as per the anti- extremist and tactics course was on under the supervision SOG Havildar and trainer Prakash Sahu at the training centre.

Unfortunately, a grenade exploded in the midair causing grievous injuries to Sahu and minor injuries to two Cadet Sergeants. All of them were rushed to a private hospital here. But Sahu succumbed to his injuries at the hospital. The conditions of the other two other personnel were stated to be stable.

DGP Abhaya expressed his condolence over the Havildar’s death.

Title: 3 held for boozing at isolation ward
Article:
Ignoring the corona-related social distancing norm, three persons in the Nuapada Krushnaprasad area of Puri district were found consuming liquor in an isolation ward of a temporary medical centre at the Nuapada gram panchayat office on Monday.

Police arrested the three persons, who included a Panchayat Samiti Member. Taking disciplinary action against the persons responsible for the incidence, the district administration suspended Panchayat Executive Officer Guru Soumyaranjan Behera for dereliction of duties.

Besides, local Gram Rojgar Sevak Mukesh Kumar Jena, who had been assigned to oversee the temporary medical centre, was also suspended by the administration.

Notably, in Puri district’s Pipili area, a person has been tested positive for the coronavirus.

Title: Nuapada wage earners a worried lot
Article:
Dhanurja Majhi and Bidyadhar Naik of Lachhipur village in Nuapada district are daily wage earners. By working in tractors, they used to earn ? 200 on an average per day.

"If the lockdown due to corona outbreak continues for long, we will be in trouble," they say. They have not yet got the advance three-month rice under NFSA, not even? 1,000 assured by the Government for ration card holders. "Still, we have to manage with our existing stocks," says Bidyadhar.

He says that rice is not a problem. "Because in addition to the rice provided under NFSA, I also have an additional stock of 150 kg of rice that I got from sharecropping. However, Dhanurja is worried because his wife was in advance stage of pregnancy during last Kharif and now they have a child that did not allow her to do wage work. "I hope the shutdown will end soon," says Dhanurja.

These two cases explain the situation of hundreds of poor wage earners of Nuapada district.

Title: Umarkote Muslims to cooperate with administration’
Article:
The Umarkote Suni Muslim community Anjuma Islamiya assured to cooperate with the administration and the police in identifying those who have attended the Tablighi Jamaat Markaz at Delhi Nizamuddin.

The Government has asked all its civic bodies and Collectors to be alert and identify those who have attended the event in Delhi and the State is on high alert seeking to locate them as several of them who have landed in other States have turned Covid-19 positive.

While sharing information with mediapersons, president of the Anjuma Islamiya Md Khalid Tanbir Jilani said that there is no single house of Sunni Muslim community of Umarkote having a link with Jamat Markaz at Delhi or ever having visited the place. However, if such activities come to fore , it would be promptly intimated to the administration for action, he added.

Jilani urged the administration to prevent rumors by some elements about the returnees of Tablighi Jamaat Markaz here and give it a communal twist. He requested all the community people to maintain harmony in the critical time to overcome the deadly pandemic.

Title: Patient shifted; 11 villages in Aul sealed
Article:
After detection of the first COVID-19 positive case on Monday in Kendrapada district in its Aul area, the administration sealed 11 villages in the area on Tuesday as a preventive measure to prevent the spread of coronavirus.

Public movement in the containment area has been strictly restricted and the administration began sanitisatising and disinfecting the area.Besides, house to house survey was being carried out by health personnel for screening of the residents, said Kendrapada Collector Samantha Verma.

“People need not to panic. Essential items will be supplied to the households,” he added.

Meanwhile, the patient was shifted to Ashwini Hospital in Cuttack and swab samples of his family members were collected and sent for testing. They have also been asked to stay in home quarantine.

Title: Coronavirus tally reaches 129 in Hry, 33 in a day
Article: After 33 more people tested positive for coronavirus, the number of cases in Haryana rose to 129 on Tuesday, a bulletin of the the state health department said. The total of 129 includes 17 patients who were discharged after they recovered and two deaths. There are 110 active cases in the State, it said.Of the 33 fresh cases reported on Tuesday, 23 are from Nuh district, seven from Faridabad, two from Gurugram and one from Jind, the health department said in its evening bulletin. Ten foreign nationals -- six from Sri Lanka, and one each from Nepal, Thailand, Indonesia and South Africa are among the cases.

Title: HP Cabinet to slash 30% salaries of MLAs for 1yr
Article:
The Himachal Pradesh Government on Tuesday decided to deduct 30 per cent salaries of State MLAs for a year to fight the COVID-19 pandemic.

In a meeting chaired by Chief Minister Jai Ram Thakur through video conferencing on Tuesday, the State Cabinet decided to deduct 30 per cent salaries and honorarium of all Members of Legislative Assembly, including the chief minister, Vidhan Sabha speaker, deputy speaker and ministers for one year.

It has also been decided to suspend the Vidhayak Kshetra Vikas Nidhi Yojna for two years, a spokesperson said.

The State Cabinet also decided to deduct 30 per cent salaries of chairmen and vice chairmen of various boards, corporations and all political appointees for one year.

On the World Health Day, the Cabinet also expressed its gratitude to the frontline ‘coronavirus warriors’ -- doctors, nurses, para medical staff, sanitary workers and police -- for their dedicated services during the COVID-19 pandemic.

The Chief Minister also hailed the decision of the Union Government to deduct 30 per cent salaries of the Prime Minister, MPs and central Ministers.

The Cabinet also paid its tributes to two Army personnels from the State-paratrooper Bal Krishan of Kullu''s Puyed village and Subedar Sanjeev Kumar of Bilaspur''s Dehra village-- who along with three other soldiers had fallen to the bullets of militants in Jammu and Kashmir on Sunday.

CM DIRECTS TO LAUNCH EXTENSIVE CAMPAIGN FOR CONTACT MAPPING OF TABLIGHI JAMAAT COVID-19 INFECTED PERSONS

Holding a video conferencing with all the Deputy Commissioners, Superintendents of Police and Chief Medical Officers of the State from Shimla on Tuesday, Chief Minister Jai Ram Thakur directed the officers that extensive campaign must be launched for contact mapping of Tablighi Jamaat coronavirus infected persons so that it does not multiply further.

"Such persons should be kept in quarantine till they were not medically examined," he told the officers. He also urged the people to come forward to identify such people in their areas to check further spread of coronavirus.

Thakur said that State Government would not hesitate in taking strict action against those who would conceal information about their travelling history and those who give shelter to them.

He said the ESI Hospital Katha in Baddi area of Solan district has been notified as Hospital for treatment of COVID-19 positive patients and patients from Solan and Sirmaur districts would be treated in this hospital.

The CM said the State Government had started tele-medicine consultancy facilities in Health and Wellness centres to facilitate the people in getting treatment advise from specialists.

Thakur said that under the Active Case Finding Campaign launched throughout the State, health information of 41 lakh persons were collected by the health workers during door to door campaign, adding that adequate arrangements should be made for providing surgical masks, hand sanitizers and gloves to the health workers working under Active Case Finding Campaign.

He said 4684 persons had been kept under surveillance for coronavirus in the State so far out of which 2188 people had completed 28 days of surveillance period, adding that investigations of 79 persons for COVID-19 had been done in the State on Tuesday out of which 22 samples have been found negative and report of 57 samples were still awaited.

GOVERNOR HONOURS HEALTH WORKERS ON WORLD HEALTH DAY

Himachal Governor Bandaru Dattatraya on Tuesday honoured the doctors, nurses and safai karamchari at Raj Bhavan on World Health Day while following social distancing norms. He said the whole world was fighting with coronavirus pandemic, which increases the importance of this Day.

In the wake of the coronavirus, millions of doctors, nurses, medical staff and healthcare workers were leaving behind their comfort and safety to fight COVID-19 crisis and help those infected or suspected of coronavirus. “We should salute their spirit and give them full respect”, said the Governor.

Title: Govt to Tablighis: Come out of hiding or face prosecution’
Article:
Setting a 24-hour deadline to all Tablighi Jamaat (TJ) participants of the Delhi Nizamuddin Markaz event hiding out in the State, Punjab Government on Tuesday asked them to report to the nearest police station or else face criminal prosecution.

“All those, who had attended the TJ event at Nizamuddin Markaz and are currently in, Punjab should report and appear for COVID-19 screening within the next 24 hours,” said the state Health Department’s spokesperson.

Of the 467 Tabligh Jamaat workers who had reportedly come to Punjab from Nizamuddin, the police had, so far, traced 445 participants, with 22 yet to be tracked. Samples had been collected and tested for 350 of those traced, and of these, 12 had been found positive and 111 negative. The results for the remaining 227 were awaited, said the spokesperson.

While taking care of the sensitivity of the issue, the remaining TJ participants have been asked to come out for testing and join hands with the Punjab Government to eliminate this disease from the country.

Spokesperson cited reports that the Markaz of TJ had emerged as a hotspot of COVID-19 positive patients, with subsequent confirmation of many positive cases among TJ workers.

It may be recalled that the Union Ministry of Home Affairs has already issued an advisory on March 28 and, in its continuation, reiterated its directions to all the Chief Secretaries or Advisors to Administrators of all States or UTs and DGPs in this regard on April 4.

Title: No new COVID-19 case on Tuesday
Article:
In what can be termed as a relief amid increasing instances of the novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) cases in the State from last few days no new case of the disease was reported by the state health and family welfare department on Tuesday. In Uttarakhand 31 patients of the disease have so far been reported and out of them five have recovered from the disease and discharged from the hospitals. Acting swiftly after large number of the Talbilghi Jamaat followers and those who came into contact with them were traced, the health department sent about 27000 people in different parts of the state into quarantine on Tuesday. With them the number of people in institutional and home quarantine in the state jumped to 45415.

The additional health secretary and mission director, National Health Mission (NHM), Yugal Kishore Pant said that reports of 126 suspected patients of the disease was received by the department on Tuesday and all of them were found negative for the disease.

He said that reports of 166 samples are still awaited. Pant added that a total of 1289 swab samples of suspected patients have so far been taken for COVID-19 test. On Tuesday, samples of 164 suspected patients was taken and sent to the lab for test. Pant informed that 23 new isolation wards for the patients of the disease were set up in the state on Tuesday.

He said that 1681 isolation beds have been prepared by the department. Pant added that due to increase in number of patients 45 new quarantine facilities were prepared on Tuesday.

A total of 15089 beds are now available in 547 quarantine facilities in the state. In another development the medical education department has started online classes for the medical and nursing students of the state so that their studies are completed on time.

Pant also informed that proper security would be provided to the Asha workers engaged in the awareness campaign for the COVID-19 and contact tracing of the patients of the disease. The Chief Medical Officers (CMO) have been directed to provide masks and other safety equipment to the Asha workers, he added.

Title: Keonjhar Covid hosp in 2 weeks
Article:
An agreement has been signed with the Utkal Hospitals Pvt Ltd, Bhubaneswar to establish and manage a dedicated 200-bed COVID-19 Hospital at Keonjhar.

The hospital would be used to treat COVID-19 suspected and positive persons in the district. It would be well-equipped in terms of human resources, infrastructure and biomedical equipments such as ICUs, ventilators and patient monitoring devices.

The hospital located near Ranki is expected to be fully functional within next two weeks and would be entirely funded from the DMF.

As preventive measures, police have so far seized more than 850 vehicles for violation of lockdown norms in the district while 45 other violators have been sent to quarantine centres for 14 days. The Collector has asked to start collecting fines from persons not using masks while moving outside.

Title: Woman kills 3-yr-old daughter in B’ngir
Article:
A woman allegedly killed her three-year-old daughter, whose body was recovered from a pond at Talpalipada in Balangir district on Tuesday.

Locals found the body floating in the pond. Receiving information, the girl’s father Prasanna Bag, a resident of Thikadarpada village, rushed to the spot and recovered the body.

Later, he went to the Town police station and lodged a complaint alleging that the girl was killed by her mother Satya.

He alleged that his wife had eloped with her paramour on March 21 leaving her two daughters with him.

On Monday evening, Satya came to the house and took away younger daughter Soumya with her. Later, Satya and her paramour killed the child, alleged Prasanna.

Title: Rs 7L collected from lockdown violators in B’pur
Article:
After the lockdown, the Ganjam administration is strictly enforcing a shutdown which was in force for the last couple of days in Brahmapur city and other parts of the district.

The police also acted tough on the violators and collected fines of Rs 7 lakh besides registering a number of cases on April 5 and 6. The cops also seizing the vehicles of those, who are violating the guidelines of the Government and were moving around in the guise of purchasing groceries and other essential items.

The equipments required for coronavirus testing have also arrived at the MKCG Medical College Hospital in the city. The medical staffs are being provided with required training for operating them. After being functional the facility can test 17 swab samples in a day.

Ganjam Collector Vijay Amruta Kulange had directed people to wear masks while venturing out of their homes. But seven violators were penalised for not wearing masks. The Tata Hospital has been kept in readiness for treating COVID- 19 patients. The DIG and the SP also visited the police barracks and took stock of the situation there.

Title: 6 held, Rs 42.5K fine collected in JSpur
Article:
Police arrested six persons and collected fine worth Rs 42,500 in the last 24 hours (from 8 am on Monday to 8 am on Tuesday) for allegedly violating the Covid-19 lockdown norms in Jagatsingpur district.

Four cases were registered at separate police stations in the districts for violation of lockdown guidelines in the period and six persons were arrested in this connection.

Besides, the police collected Rs 42,500 as fine after checking around 96 vehicles in the last 24 hours, said a District Intelligence Bureau release.

Of the four cases, the Abhaychandrapur police seized a car transporting 75 litre of illegal liquor and arrested three occupants of the vehicle.

Another person was arrested by the Nuagaon police while carrying five litre of illegal liquor.

Meanwhile, security in the area was further tightened to enforce the lockdown for in the district.

Title: DRDO develops sanitising gadgets to fight corona
Article:
In the continuing quest for developing indigenous solutions to combat the coronavirus pandemic, the Defence Research and Development Organisation (DRDO) is ready with technologies for sanitising areas of different sizes.

The Centre for Fire Explosive and Environment Safety (CFEES), Delhi has developed two configurations of sanitising equipment. These are spinoffs from technologies developed for fire suppression applications, said a Press release issued by the DRDO.

The equipment developed are Portable Backpack Area Sanitisation Equipment and Trolley Mounted Large Area Sanitisation Equipment.

The CFEES, Delhi with the help of its industry partner has developed portable sanitisation equipment for spraying decontamination solution consisting of one per cent hypochlorite (HYPO) solution for sanitisation of suspected area. The portable system can be mounted as a backpack and can be carried by the operations personnel. This system incorporates low pressure twin fluid (air and disinfectant liquid) technology to generate very fine mist. The system is capable of disinfecting up to 300 square metre area. The application areas can include hospital reception, doctor chambers, office spaces dealing with general public, corridors, pathways, metro and railway stations, bus stations, etc.

The Centre with the help of its industry partner has also developed a higher capacity which is carried on a trolley. The system incorporates low pressure single fluid (disinfectant liquid) technology generating very fine mist. It is capable of disinfecting up to 3,000 square metre area.

It has a tank capacity of 50 litres and has a lancing (throw) distance of 12-15 metres. This is useful for disinfecting hospitals, malls, airports, metro stations, isolation areas, quarantine centres and high risk residential areas.

Two of these systems are being provided to Delhi Police for immediate use. These can be made available to other agencies with the help of industry partners, the release mentioned.

Title: Fake liquor racket busted; 2 held
Article:
The Town police on Monday busted a racket that used to sell fake Indian Made Foreign Liquor (IMFL) and arrested two persons in this connection.

The cops also seized Rs 28 lakh from their possession.

The arrested persons were identified as Abinash Gupta of Bhatli Road of Bargarh town and Satrughan Gupta of Balangir district. Besides, the money police have seized stickers of reputed IMFL brands, materials for manufacturing liquor and fake liquor bottles from them.

Bargarh SP Padmini Sahoo a case 140/20 has been registered against them andfurther investigations are on. Among other ASP Amarendra Rana and Town PS IIC Sadanand Pujhari were present.

Title: JSPL achieves record output, sales
Article:
The Jindal Steel & Power Limited (JSPL) reported its highest-ever domestic and overseas steel and related products production and sales during the financial year (FY) 20.

The company's major steel production units in Raigarh, Angul and Oman recorded the highest ever production and sales of steel and related products. Its domestic operations also continued to ramp up significantly.

The company's domestic steel and related products production increased to a record of 6.3 MT (up 13% y-o-y) during FY 20 and sales increased to 6 MT (up 12% y-o-y).

Title: 303 Americans, Canadians evacuated from Punjab
Article:
USA Embassy and Canadian High Commission on Tuesday ran special chartered flights from Amritsar to evacuate their citizens and Permanent Residents or Green Card Holders from Punjab.

In all, there are 208 passengers on the flight for Canada, which will go via New Delhi and Heathrow, London, to Toronoto, while there are 95 passengers in the flight to the USA, via New Delhi to San Francisco.

“All the passengers were properly screened before being allowed to board,” said the state’s Special Chief Secretary KBS Sidhu adding that the flights to other countries, including the UK are possible in the coming few days.

Title: Muslim leaders issue appeal to follow guidelines in UT
Article:
To ensure social distancing and effective implementation of curfew restrictions in the city, the religious leaders from Muslim community on Tuesday issued an appeal to people to follow the Administration’s guidelines.

The joint press conference by various leaders from across the city came after UT Police request. SSP Nilambari Jagadale was also present during the conference at Jama Masjid, Sector 20 here.

In a joint appeal, Maullana Ajmal Khan of Jama Masjid Sector 20, Maullana Imran of Masjid Manimajra, Mufti Anas of Masjid BDC-26, Quari Shamsher of Masjid Sector 45 and Noor, member of Tablighi Jamaat Chandigarh urged the community to stay at home and follow the curfew restrictions put in place to combat the spread of COVID-19 in the city.

Title: Chief Minister pays tribute to martyred soldiers
Article:
Chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat paid tribute to martyred army soldiers Devendra Singh and Amit Kumar after their bodies were brought to their home districts on Tuesday.

Singh’s body was brought by helicopter to Guptkashi where the CM laid a wreath on his coffin. Garhwal MP Teerath Singh Rawat and Kedarnath MLA Manoj Rawat also paid tributes to the martyr.

At Ransi in Pauri, the CM laid a wreath on the coffin of martyr Kumar. Stating that Uttarakhand is the land of the braves, he said that the state Government is committed to support the families of the martyrs. It will be recalled that Singh and Kumar were among the five Indian soldiers killed in action while fighting five terrorists who were also eliminated in the encounter in Jammu and Kashmir on Sunday.

Title: Social Media: Distinct mode of communication in social distancing
Article:
The people of India were deeply influenced when Prime Minister Narendra Modi first addressed the nation about the scale of COVID-19 crisis and announced Janata Curfew which was later converted into 21-day nationwide lockdown in public interest. In his address to Nation whether on DD National or on Mann Ki Baat on All India Radio (AIR) he stressed on the need of social distancing as the main measure to prevent the spread of COVID-19 and also for better and healthy tomorrow.

Humans by their very nature are social. May be keeping this in mind the PM also urged people not to have emotional and human distancing while observing social distancing. A question which arises is how to reduce interpersonal distance while maintaining social distancing. One of the answers lies in prudent, proactive and purposeful use of social media as these days it has emerged more as an interpersonal mode of communication rather than a mere medium of information and entertainment.

People posting their pictures of “work from home” on Facebook, donation in Prime Minister National Relief Fund (PMNRF) #PMCARES is trending on Twitter, people cooking food and posting on Instagram and throwing “cooking challenge” to their friends on social media, various jokes on WhatsApp on lock down and last but not the least never ending web series have just shown all of us that how social media tools have kept us be in touch even though we are not actually touching each other. Facebook and You Tube were flooded with “Thaali & Taali Tribute” videos of people showing their solidarity towards people working to keep all of us safe at our homes risking their own lives. COVID-19 web application showing the status of present cases in India helping people to be informed in this era of less contact with outside world. YouTube and other social media platforms are flooded with workout videos and people are throwing “fitness challenge” to each other.

Video chat/call on Skype, WhatsApp and other platforms to know the wellbeing of family and friends has become normal in our lives. People are donating contributions in PM CARES fund and other governmental funds through digital payment and posting it on social media to inspire others too. This is yet another shining example of social bonding via social media platforms.

MyGov Corona Hub has become a one stop destination of authorised information and feedback. #IndiaFightsCorona is one of the hash tags that are trending on social media. MyGov Corona Hub also launched an online competition on its web portal for people to suggest possible solutions to tackle the problem of spread of COVID-19 and the possible solutions. The competition also had the provision of Rs one lakh cash prize.

Most of us have heard the caller tune while we were on mobile calls that informs us about preventive measures against the spread of COVID-19. This is an innovative and yet very timely initiative of the government that deserves a big round of applause. Even Facebook has also started COVID-19 Information Centre for latest updates. Keeping in mind the reach, access and penetration among masses of these social media platform this idea can contribute to a greater extent to keep people well informed and updated. People are posting dedicated display picture of “Stay home…Stay safe” to mark their solidarity with this lockdown process.

Radio has also emerged as a vital communication tool in present scenario. The PM in his video conference with noted radio anchors of the country had urged them to play an important role in spreading awareness through radio to stop the spread of COVID-19.

The instantaneous nature of social media platforms such as Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Snapchat, has created a new way for us to connect and share information. Today we interact, comment and share anything, anytime. According to a recent media report of Economic Times, mobile internet usage had increased around 10 per cent on average since the start of the lockdown, barring metros like Delhi and Mumbai which have seen as little as 3 per cent rise. The small telecom circles have recorded higher growth at 15 per cent.

Due to present lockdown people are compelled to stay at home and internet surfing has become one of the effective ways of engagement. At the same time when elderly, young persons and kids are together spending time at home which in all likelihood could enhance the level of digital literacy among who were till recently not very enthusiastic about using social media.

(AN Tripathy is a DGM, Gaurav Kumar is social media officer at THDC)

Title: Every grain would be procured: CM assures farmers
Article:
Amid apprehension by farmers on Wheat procurement ahead of the harvest, Haryana Chief Minister Manohar Lal Khattar on Tuesday assured the farming community that every grain of their produce will be procured and purchase centres have been increased this time to allow “staggered” procurement in view of the lockdown.

Khattar said farmers who store their harvested wheat crop for longer durations may be given incentives.

For the procurement, which normally begins on April 1, the state government this time has said for wheat it will begin from April 20 and for mustard from April 15.

“We have written to Centre that farmers should be paid ''holding incentive'' for delaying bringing their produce to ’mandis’ (wholesale markets),” Khattar told reporters through video conference. He said as against 433 purchase centres and mandis last time, this season these have been increased to 2,000 to allow staggered procurement of wheat, which is likely to last over a month.

The chief minister said ''Arhitiyas'' will be involved in procurement process. The government will digitally transfer payments to them who in turn will pay it to the farmers for the crop procured, he said.

However, for mustard, farmers will be directly paid by the government, Khattar said. “For mustard we will make purchases from April 15 and for this, from 66 mandis earlier it will be 140 mandis this time… We are committed to procuring every single grain of farmers,” he said.

The chief minister said that in view of the COVID-19 pandemic, cloth masks will be made available to farmers when they come to mandis and purchase centres.

He appealed to farmers to voluntary donate at least the sum they would earn on 1-5 kg per quintal of their crop produce. He said that all sections of society, including state government employees, have made contributions towards

the Haryana COVID Relief Fund.

Khattar said that while all legislators had decided to donate their month's salary for the COVID Relief Fund, the governor, the deputy CM, assembly speaker, deputy speaker, ministers and him from their discretionary quota have contributed amount ranging between Rs 2 crore to Rs 3 crore towards the Consolidated Fund of India, making it total of Rs 51 crore.

On the farmers issue, he assured that despite the lockdown they will not be allowed to face any problem when it comes to movement of agricultural equipment, including tractors and combine harvesting machines.

With many migrant workers from the state having left for their hometown in Uttar Pradesh and Bihar over a week ago in the wake of lockdown, he said directions have been given in districts to make labourers under the MGNREGA.

He admitted that farmers will have to cooperate this time as availability of labour was going to be a problem.

On March 28 and 29, many migrant labourers who were present in Haryana or came from neighbouring states like Punjab crossed through the state to go to their hometowns in view of their apprehensions about the lockdown.

“Some left (for their native states) and some were stopped. Today, there are nearly 15,000 migrant labourers who have been accommodated in our relief camps. These 15,000, if they want to go their factory or state where they work, if they want to go in a safe manner, we can make efforts to send them back by following all norms pertaining to COVID-19 so that sufficient distance is maintained in buses, like in each bus 20-30 people can be accommodated and sent to their homes. During the past two days 1,000 such people have gone back,” he said.

Khattar also said that state government had taken steps to provide food and ration to poor sections including daily wagers and so far, 55 lakh food packets and 3.5 lakh ration packets have been distributed.

On the Haryana COVID Relief Fund, he said there was no coercion on employees, but so far 1.82 lakh employees have come forward on their own making healthy contributions.

Title: Delhi Govt fails to inform about dead cop's virus infection: Anil Vij
Article:
Haryana Government on Tuesday lodged a protest with the Delhi government, alleging that they failed to inform them about a State police Sub Inspector who died at a hospital in the national capital after contracting COVID-19.

Charging some of the deceased's family members and the hospital with concealing information, cases have also been registered against them.

Haryana Home Minister Anil Vij said the SI from Sonipat was admitted to a private hospital in Delhi last month after he suffered a brain stroke. Later, he contracted coronavirus infection and passed away on Saturday.

Neither the Delhi government nor hospital authorities or even the deceased's family gave any information that he had tested positive for the infection, the minister said. "On Tuesday, we lodged a strong protest with the Delhi government and our state chief secretary talked to her counterpart in this regard. A sub-inspector of the Haryana police died in Delhi, but we were not informed," Vij said.

The minister said they handed over the body to the family, which also concealed the information. "Many people participated in the deceased's last rites in Sonipat and several of his colleagues from the police station where he worked also took part in the funeral. He was also given a gun salute. Later, we learnt that he had tested COVID positive," Vij said.

“I enquired from my officials about this, but they said they had no information. This is a big lapse on part of the Delhi government that they failed to inform us,” he said. Vij said 30-40 people, including police officials and some members of the deceased's family have been quarantined after the revelation.

“A case has also been registered against some of the deceased's family members under Sections 269 and 270 of the IPC for concealing the information. We have also registered a case against the Delhi hospital,” he said.

Title: People support the needy through Doon Happy Meals
Article:
More than 2000 cooked food packets have been distributed by Dehradun district administration to those in need during the lockdown through the online initiative Doon Happy Meals. Dry ration kits are also being donated by the locals and various organisations of Dehradun.

The number of people and organisations supporting the Dehradun district administration through Doon Happy Meals is increasing every day in providing the food and ration kits to needy during the lockdown period.

So far the administration has received more than 2000 cooked food packets or happy meal kit including 130 such kits on Tuesday through this initiative. Besides the cooked meal packets, over 500 Annapurna kits have also been donated through the initiative including 236 such kits on Tuesday.

Informing about the cooked food packets, Dehradun Chief Development Officer (CDO) Nikita Khandelwal said, "We prefer the meals in cooked food kits to be durable which does not get spoiled within few hours. For example, food with lots of tomatoes will get spoiled within few hours, therefore we have given the options on the website of Doon Happy

Meals that include Dal-Chawal, Puri-Chole or Pulao which do not spoil within a few hours."

She further added, when the administration receives an application for the donation, the donor is contacted and on a given date the team from administration does the inspection of the kitchen or surrounding of the place where the food will be prepared.

Only after this process, the application of cooking meals is approved by the administration, said Khandelwal. However, for the donation of cooked food packets, an applicant has to prepare at least 50 food packets otherwise the kit will not be picked up by the administration.

For the Annapurna kits, at least five packets of dry ingredients should be donated. The Annapurna kits should have the ingredients which are listed on the website that include Dal, oil, flour, rice, salt, pepper, and sugar among others. Khandelwal also informed that at least 15 applications are being received daily through the Happy Meals website. So far around 100 applications have been received by the district administration, added Khandelwal.

Apart from the happy meals, the district administration distributed 4,644 cooked food packets on Tuesday with the help of several voluntary organizations and individuals including Power of Togetherness, Radhaswami Satsang Vyas, Shri Guru Angad Devji Gurudwara, Doon University, Jinesh Sehgal and Durga Verma among others.

Title: JBIT begins online classes
Article: JB Institute of Technology (JBIT) institute has started online classes for all the students in view of the State-wide lockdown. According to the institute vice-chairman Sandeep Singhal, around 2500 students are studying online at their homes.
